subject: IPv6 VIP addresses need to be /128
commit_message:
IPv6 VIP addresses need to be /128

We currently hardcode /64 as our VIP addresses when using IPv6.
The problem with this is that some server code might bind to that
IP as a source address when doing inter-cluster communication
(rabbitmq/galera for example). So when the VIP moves there will
be effectively a network outage between the nodes, which should not
happen.

Likely this was hardcoded to /64 because the RA IPaddr2 needs a nic
parameter when /128 is specified. This is due to:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1445628

We also make sure we use the ipv6_addrlabel option set to 99 so that
they will never be used as source ip addresses.

Due to Tox override mechanism, both py27 and py34 envs do not pass
env variables defined in testenv to tox_install.sh script. Hence,
BRANCH_NAME is not defined and master code of Horizon is always

tox -e py27 fails due to fresh Horizon and old its dependencies.

defined in testenv will be also defined in these both envs.

All cache operations and dnsmasq process operations

This patch adjusts the DHCP agent to lock based on
network ID rather than having a global lock for every

subject: tests: Send more ICMP packets to determime external connectivity
commit_message:
tests: Send more ICMP packets to determime external connectivity

We use ping to determine if the container has external connectivity.
We also use the management IP in Ansible to connect to the container
which is in a different interface than the external one. The management
interface has a static IP so it's available much earlier than the
external one which obtains the IP via DHCP. As such, in some cases,
the external interface may not be configured early enough and the ping
fails. We can improve this situation by sending more ICMP packets less
frequently to give the interface sometime to be configured properly.
This patch effectively allows 30 seconds for interface to reach a working

subject: Fix up race when setting a property
commit_message:
Fix up race when setting a property

Back in January when we moved the property support implementation to
ruby the 'require' line got lost. This makes it so that there is a race
where we set a property but the cluster might not be fully up and so we
might fail when dumping the CIB:

May  4 13:46:44 centos-7-2-node-osic-cloud1-s3500-8719947-570244
os-collect-config:  Error: unable to get cib
Error: /Stage[main]/Pacemaker::Stonith/Pacemaker::Property[Disable
STONITH]/Pcmk_property[property--stonith-enabled]: Could not evaluate:
backup_cib: Running: /usr/sbin/pcs cluster cib
/var/lib/pacemaker/cib/puppet-cib-backup20170504-29225-fetp7k failed
with code: 1 ->

Am not entirely sure why I saw this only today in a failed CI job, but

Mount hostpath logs on /var/log

Some containers are using the logs named volume for collecting logs
written to `/var/log`. We should make this consistent for all the

subject: XenAPI: fix memory usage miscalculation
commit_message:
XenAPI: fix memory usage miscalculation

Although hypervisor will report the used memory to resource tracker, but
resource tracker won't use that value. Instead it will calculate the
used memory basing the reserved memory and memory used by intances. This
calculation doesn't count the memory used by the hypervisor itself (dom0
in XenServer) and also doesn't count the memory used by VMs which were
booted outside of OpenStack (e.g. the compute/controller nodes running
on the hosts). So scheduler may proceed instance's claiming even when
there actually isn't enough free memory.

This fix proposes to add a new method to virt drivers so they can report
a dynamic reserved memory which include the memory has been used by VMs
which were booted outside of OpenStack. Resource tracker will compare it
with the staticly configured reserved memory and pick up the larger one.
So the backward compatability will also be guaranteed.

Change-Id: I22e5a8fcea870c508f3451337e6be91371fe7aa5
Closes-Bug: #1642494

subject: Use dict arg values for unicode checks in ContextFormatter
commit_message:
Use dict arg values for unicode checks in ContextFormatter

In ContextFormatter.format(), for python2 it checks each arg to
determine whether unicode should be used for the format message.
The problem is the code assumes the args are a list, when they can
also be a dict, for example:

  LOG.info('%(thing)s', {'thing': '...'})

and in that case, the dict keys were implicitly being used for the
checks. The checks will always pass on string dict keys, so the
format message gets converted to unicode even though the corresponding
args will ultimately fail decoding to unicode. Then, the logging fails
with:

  UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc6 in
  position 0: ordinal not in range(128)

when the unicode format message causes an implicit conversion attempt
of the args to unicode [1].

This adds a check for the args type and uses the dict values for the
unicode checks so that dict args with values that fail decoding will
have: should_use_unicode = False.

Closes-Bug: #1580728

[1] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/2e576f5/Lib/logging/__init__.py#L338
